Well good evening everyone and welcome. It’s
my pleasure as Chancellor to welcome you to

17.text:
this evening’s lecturer and to introduce
him. He doesn’t really need any introduction. I

22.text:
had some notes that were prepared for me to
introduce the Archbishop but I listened to

33.text:
the 1 o’clock News and from that, not only
did I learn of the Archbishop’s future retirement

43.text:
and it’s not taking place now, it’s taking

50.text:
I also heard a little bit about his CV, a
Professor of Theology at Oxford in his 30s

58.text:
and I believe we have some other Oxford Professors
of Theology and I don’t know whether they’re

63.text:
current or past, a Bishop at 40 and of course
then Archbishop of Wales and then of Canterbury. I

77.text:
think that the piece on the BBC, and I said
this to the Archbishop, did pay tribute to

89.text:
him in a number of ways: it said he hadn’t
been looking to become the Archbishop of Canterbury,

95.text:
it was a case of greatness being thrust upon
him. He no doubt achieved greatness in other

104.text:
ways but he also had greatness thrust upon

123.text:
suspect figures like the Archbishop are not

131.text:
but it seemed to me it was a very nice piece,
Dr Williams, that I heard and no doubt many

137.text:
many others did. 
Of course we know that he is a hugely distinguished

144.text:
academic, apart from the enormously important
work that he has done as Leader of the Anglican

153.text:
Church. Beyond that he’s published many

159.text:
on Russian Theology. Well, when Dr Williams
became Archbishop and was ready to make his

168.text:
first visit to Rome to meet the late Pope
John Paul II he was asked by the press perhaps

175.text:
a little mischievously what he was going to
talk to the Pope about. His reply was ‘our

180.text:
common interest in Hans von Balthazar’. Von
Balthazar, I should think that the press looking

187.text:
a little bit surprised and wondering what
on earth was going to come next. Well, von

194.text:
Balthazar was the Swiss Theologian well known

201.text:
and in that reply can be discerned Dr Williams

206.text:
that he’s going to address in a moment. 
This evening’s lecture concludes the 2012

214.text:
series of Edward Cadbury lectures. Edward
Cadbury was my oldest uncle and he was a very

223.text:
interesting man and a very important figure,
certainly in the development of the Cadbury

229.text:
business. He ran the Cadbury business following
my grandfather for many years from pretty

235.text:
much the First War to the Second War. So he
was somebody though that I knew, I couldn’t

242.text:
say well but as a small boy I do remember
him pretty well and he was a great disciplinarian

251.text:
and was known in fact to stand outside the
factory doors, checking who was coming in

257.text:
late to work in the morning. No doubt this
certainly would have struck a little surprise

265.text:
and a certain amount of fear into those that
were late, but he was actually a man of great

271.text:
humanity and with many interests that went
beyond the business. He was an author and

280.text:
wrote some books on industry in 1912 or thereabouts
which I suspect not many businessmen of his

288.text:
era would have written and certainly not the
subjects and when you read what he wrote in

296.text:
those days you can tell that he was a man
of great humanity. His books were concerned

304.text:
with the experiments industrial organisation,
also on women’s work and wages.

312.text:
I don’t suppose many businessmen overly
concern themselves with whether women’s

317.text:
work and wages were properly related in those
days. Also a book on sweating, a form of

325.text:
exploiting labour. Now these were all being
published before the First World War so he

332.text:
was a man who was very very far-sighted and
a great friend of this university, having

338.text:
endowed the First Chair of Theology and of
course endowed this series of lectures in

347.text:
his name. He always took a great interest
in Christianity and in other faiths and the

353.text:
Selly Oak Colleges were something that he
put a great deal of time and interest to and

361.text:
the Mingana Collection which some of you may
have seen was also the result of the collection

368.text:
of artefacts, religious artefacts, from the
Middle East that he was responsible for. So

374.text:
someone who’s been a great friend of the
university and I was quite curious when I

378.text:
saw in the book before I came that it was
priced at 1 shilling and sixpence. You’ve

385.text:
got to go back quite a long way before you
can find a book that was only costing 1 shilling

391.text:
and sixpence. And in fact the preface was
by a Professor Ashley who was the Professor

399.text:
or Commerce at the university so we had the
School of Commerce and a Professor of Commerce

404.text:
back before the First War. 
Well, enough about Edward but he has been

412.text:
a great friend of the university and I wanted
to mention him. The endowment for the lectures

418.text:
was to bring the best of international scholarship
on History, Theology and Culture of Christianity

425.text:
to the people of the Midlands and beyond.
The theme of the lectures this year has been

432.text:
‘Seeing and Believing in Modern Christianity’
and Professor David Morgan who is among us

438.text:
this evening has outlined some of the ways
in which images and culture have interacted

447.text:
in Christianity in the recent past. Associated
with the lectures the university has just

453.text:
concluded a conference on the sense of the
sacred in contemporary China, with Dr Williams

460.text:
taking part in dialogue with Chinese artists
and academics. It seems a fitting conclusion

467.text:
therefore that we now ask Dr Williams to conclude
this series of lectures and events with his

473.text:
own lecture, ‘Idols, Images and Icons’. Thank

480.text:
Chancellor, ladies and gentlemen, it’s a
great honour to be invited to deliver one

497.text:
of the Cadbury lectures this year and a great
personal pleasure to back in the University

502.text:
of Birmingham. As you’ve heard, we’ve
had a most stimulating and energising day

507.text:
of discussion and so stimulating and energising
has it been that I have managed, in spite

513.text:
of all temptations, to keep my mind on it
rather than on other things in the news today. The

522.text:
Hebrew language is well known for its fondness
for neo-synonyms. Again and again in the Hebrew

531.text:
scriptures we find pairs and triplets of words
slightly different in their associations and

538.text:
their resonances where we might be tempted
to use only one. And one such pair of closely

545.text:
related words appears right at the beginning
of scripture when we are told that God created

553.text:
human beings in the image and likeness of
God. The two different words used that we

562.text:
translate as image and likeness gave great
scope for imaginative interpreters of the

569.text:
Bible for many centuries. Some of the early
Greek theologians of the Church tried to draw

575.text:
out a distinction between the image, which
was something given, and the likeness into

580.text:
which we were allowed to grow. But the distinction
in Hebrew is of a rather different kind and

588.text:
the two words used are well worth looking
at in the context of a general reflection

594.text:
on images and idols and icons. The two words
in question are selem and demut. The word

606.text:
selem, which we translate as image is related
to a root ‘sel’ which means ‘shadow’. And

619.text:
the word selem itself can also mean something
insubstantial, something that is nothing in

626.text:
particular, something that is impermanent.
And that root sense of shadow suggests very

637.text:
strongly that the notion of imaging that is
implied here takes for granted that at the

646.text:
heart of the image there is an absence, something
less than real.

654.text:
Representing is embodying an absence and that
may help us to understand why in so much of

662.text:
the Hebrew scriptures in other places we find
idolatry depicted as devotion to what is not

670.text:
there. Idolatry is directing your adoration
to an unreality and if you turn to the central

682.text:
chapters of the Prophecy of Isaiah, the section
usually known as Deutero-Isaiah, you find

688.text:
repeated polemic against idolatry couched
in these terms. The image, the idol, sometimes

699.text:
referred to as selem, sometimes by words relating
to the root fasal which is about engraving

706.text:
or moulding. Images and idols are empty things.
They cannot act and in the prophet’s mind

718.text:
they cannot even be the channels of activity.
They’re the result of human activity. These

727.text:
are things that we have made. We engage in making
an image we set it there outside ourselves

736.text:
and then we bow down before this alienated
part of ourselves. The implication is that

746.text:
we are in some sense worshipping ourselves. We
cannot create a presence, a numinous presence,

756.text:
so all that we can do is to externalise what
is in our own minds and hearts, yet by externalising

765.text:
it we make ourselves absent from the work
that is made. We are subject to stand over

772.text:
against an object which we imagine, or decide
to imagine, to be something that is not us. It

781.text:
is and it isn’t us; it’s part of our imagining
and yet we have put it there outside ourselves.

789.text:
What is not going on here is anything other
than human action, human projection. We let

797.text:
go of what we make and so we make it lifeless
and that kind of language about the lifelessness,

806.text:
the emptiness, of images and idols, that polemic
about bowing down to the work of our hands,

813.text:
the result of our imagination, is of course
a common currency, a very great deal of a

820.text:
polemic of the prophets of Hebrew scripture
against what they understand to be the religious

826.text:
practices of the nations around them.
Image is a shadow. The image embodies not

836.text:
a presence but an absence. The image is what
is already in us yet something we arbitrarily

845.text:
decide to treat as if it were other. The
tradition continues in some parts of early

853.text:
Christian theology so that in the second Christian
century you’ll find Tertullian speaking

859.text:
about idolatry and noting that the Greek word
‘idolon’ can mean ‘a phantom’. If

868.text:
that’s where you begin, it is of course
perfectly intelligible that you should be

876.text:
suspicious of representation itself in some
way. This is not only a religious but a cultural

884.text:
issue. If all art is a matter of shadow and
impermanence to go back to the root meanings

894.text:
behind the word selem then all art is potentially
both deceitful and self-referential. It does

903.text:
not take you beyond yourself, it does not
heal, it does not save.  It’s against

912.text:
that background that we can perhaps better
understand the largely aniconic non-representational

919.text:
character, not only of Jewish religion but
largely of Jewish culture. The raw material

928.text:
of decoration and imagination is the written
word, not the image.

936.text:
Clearly however, in using the word selim for
the image of God in humanity, the writers

946.text:
of Genesis were not trying to say something
primarily negative. They may have had on

954.text:
the edge of their minds and imaginations that
sense of shadowiness, the phantom character

960.text:
of representation but they balance it with
another and very different word, demut. Here

970.text:
the root dem is to be like, to resemble. To
resemble, as in a comparison we might make

979.text:
in speech, even a parable. This is a representation
that takes for granted continuity rather than

990.text:
absence. It’s a way of saying not all representation
is empty or arbitrary. There is some kind

1000.text:
of being in the other, some kind of bridge
between sameness and otherness and the way

1008.text:
in which a comparison in ordinary speech,
a parable or a metaphor, may work reminds

1016.text:
us that when you’ve talked about shadowiness
and phantoms, you haven’t said all there

1021.text:
is to say about representation. And once
again, in that Jewish culture which is wary

1031.text:
about visual images, there is an abundance
of metaphor of verbal play and of parable.

1045.text:
The Genesis vocabulary in other words sets
up a basic tension about the character of

1052.text:
representation. To represent something in
something else is to say something’s missing,

1061.text:
something can’t be reproduced. This is
a shadow, not the substance. You don’t

1068.text:
have to go to Plato’s Republic to find that
kind of point being made. At the same time,

1076.text:
a representation literally embodies something
of the object it represents. It is like something

1085.text:
else. It translates into another medium, another
form of words, however you want to put it. And

1093.text:
those two words, the clusters of meanings
behind them, take religious cultures off into

1102.text:
very different directions; sometimes of course
at exactly the same time. I do wonder in passing

1110.text:
what kind of theology we might develop were
we to translate those words in Genesis by

1116.text:
saying that God created humanity as God’s
shadow and God’s parable. Elements are

1126.text:
taken off in different directions and by the
time we come to Christian scripture, a rather

1133.text:
different agenda is beginning to come into
play. The Greek word icon doesn’t have those

1143.text:
negative connotations about shadowiness or
impermanence. Sometimes the word is used

1152.text:
as in the beginning of the Letter to the Colossians
to talk about the visible sign of the invisible,

1158.text:
a token of what can’t be seen, a word for
what can’t be spoken about, yet something

1166.text:
which gives assurance about what is absent,
invisible and in some mysterious sense makes

1175.text:
it there, allows it to be active. 
The image here bridges absence and presence.

1186.text:
Behind that at least in part lies the development
of philosophy, metaphysics, in the pre-Christian

1193.text:
world outside the strict limits of Jewish
thought.  Mediation has become more of a

1203.text:
problem both in Green and in Hebrew thinking
in the immediate pre-Christian period. God’s

1210.text:
relationship to the world is coming to be
seen neither as plain absence, nor unqualified

1218.text:
presence, and both in the Jewish and the Hebraic
– both in the Jewish and the Greek worlds

1225.text:
– in those immediate pre-Christian generations,
quite complicated structures have been imagined

1232.text:
and discussed, explaining how God could be
both radically different from the world and

1238.text:
radically involved in it. One of the classic
places to look for this is a work long attributed

1247.text:
to Aristotle ‘De Mundo’ which speaks about
a distinction between God as God is and God’s

1257.text:
actions which are present in the world whereas
the essence of God is absent from the world.

1265.text:
But what seems to have crystallised this vague
metaphysical anxiety about how you build bridges

1274.text:
is the application to Jesus of Nazareth of
some of his language about imaging and mediation. When

1285.text:
Jesus was described as the ‘image of the
invisible God’ we are seeing an attempt

1293.text:
to make sense of the history and person of
Jesus in terms precisely of that mysterious

1299.text:
coincidence of absence and presence. Jesus
of Nazareth is actually irreducibly a human

1310.text:
being. He is not God in the straightforward
sense and yet what Jesus of Nazareth does

1320.text:
is what God does and where Jesus of Nazareth
is, is where God is. The image is a presence.

1330.text:
The image is, as I put it earlier, something
which gives assurance of what is not tangibly

1336.text:
there. I avoid the phrase ‘dynamic equivalence’
here, sometimes used in translation theory

1345.text:
as one which has caused far more trouble than
it’s worth, yet it carries something of

1351.text:
what this application of a certain kind of
language that Jesus is meant to convey. The

1358.text:
concept of imaging is held fairly firmly in
that area which we can designate as continuity

1367.text:
and participation between image and prototype. Jesus’
image is carrying a presence because what

1379.text:
he is and who he is, is as we might say, saturated
with the divine action, to such a degree that

1389.text:
this history and this person interrupts, overturns
and reconstructs our ordinary categories,

1398.text:
our habitual expectations. This is a reality
which first silences us and then drives us

1410.text:
to an almost chaotic exploration of ideas
and metaphors such as we find in the letters

1417.text:
of Paul and the Johanine literature.  Image
is being taken very definitively away from

1429.text:
the area of shadows and phantoms because in
speaking of Jesus as the image of God we are

1440.text:
not, in terms of Christian scripture, deciding
to treat Jesus as a token for the absent God,

1450.text:
we are recognising the interruption of our
categories and our language that occurs through

1457.text:
this narrative and in so recognising, accepting
that here is a presence acting upon us without

1467.text:
limitation or qualification. 
So as we move from the language of Hebrew

1476.text:
scripture into the language used by Paul in
his epistles by the Deutero-Paulines, by

1483.text:
the Johanine corpus or writings, we are invited
to think of imaging representing very much

1495.text:
in terms of a continuity of action. An action
so radically disturbing that we can’t come

1504.text:
to the end of it in our words, or our concepts;
an action which we therefore have to speak

1512.text:
of as divine within the Christian community. And
yet the language of image remains ambiguous.

1522.text:
In the early Christian centuries there is
debate about how far calling Jesus the image

1530.text:
of God is adequate to what Christians finally
want to say about him. In the 4th Century

1538.text:
there was much debate over this. Many people
on both sides of the great doctrinal debates

1543.text:
of that age were content to describe Jesus
as the image of God, sometimes as the complete

1552.text:
or unqualified or unmodified aparactos image
of God. But the more aggressive and keenly

1564.text:
minded of the theologians’ history was to
be described as Orthodox became more and more

1570.text:
suspicious of this language, precisely because
it was a language around which people of different

1576.text:
convictions can gather. Sadly, one of the
main drivers of the definitions of Orthodoxy

1582.text:
in the 4th Century was the urge to find formulae
that your opponents could in no circumstances

1588.text:
sign up to. And image came to be seen as
a term uneasily sitting with an affirmation

1599.text:
of the equality between the divinity that
was in Jesus and the divinity that was in

1605.text:
the Father of All Things. A doctrine of the
consubstantiality of Jesus, or rather of the

1614.text:
Word of God, with the Father. Does the language
of image do justice to that radical identification

1623.text:
between God and God’s mediator, the Everlasting
Word?  Throughout the 4th Century there

1631.text:
is a gradually developing suspicion of this
image in language of giving away too much

1639.text:
to those who wanted to emphasise a gap between
the saviour and the Eternal Father.

1648.text:
But that being said, it was that settlement
of doctrine around the person of Christ in

1655.text:
the 4th Century which in due course began
to provide a rationale for the most sophisticated

1662.text:
exploration yet of the nature of the sacred
image within the Christian framework. That

1671.text:
is the theology that emerged around the iconoclast
controversy. The great debates about the use

1680.text:
of sacred images which tore apart the Byzantine
Empire between the late 7th and the 9th Centuries. On

1691.text:
two different occasions, Byzantine emperors
attempted to do away with representational

1699.text:
images in churches and the theology that was
developed in reaction to this was a theology

1707.text:
which insisted that the sacred image was allowable
in church and in the liturgy, precisely because

1716.text:
of what the church said about Jesus Christ. Of
course, the Holy Image was something created

1725.text:
by human skill, by human art, and yet it was
something open to the same presence that was

1735.text:
in Jesus and his mother and the saints because
the skill, the art, of the artist was subordinated

1750.text:
to prayer and openness to grace on the one
hand, and on the other because the reality,

1758.text:
the historical reality of Jesus showed that
the material stuff of this world could be

1765.text:
suffused, saturated, with divine action and
divine presence. Matter could be transfigured

1775.text:
so there was a rationale for the Holy Image
in church. It was created in prayer for the

1782.text:
purpose of liturgical worship. It was made
in prayer and used in prayer and because of

1790.text:
the context in which it was set, it could
be a vehicle of active divine grace.

1797.text:
So the Eastern Christian theology of the icon,
the Holy Image, becomes probably the most

1807.text:
powerful statement of presence in the image
at one of the spectrum, at the other end of

1814.text:
which stands the idea of image as shadow.  So
moving from idol to image to icon, is moving

1830.text:
from a representation of which we are suspicious
because it is simply a reflection of what

1840.text:
is already in us, through a sense of what
is in some sense continuous with the subject

1849.text:
that it points to, to fully fledged theological
doctrine of an image in which presence and

1859.text:
action are unequivocally at work. And to
look at the history of Christian attitudes

1868.text:
to imagery, to visual imagery in church and
out of church is to look at attitudes which

1877.text:
belong somewhere along that spectrum of concern.
In the Reformation period what we see in the

1887.text:
reaction against holy images in this country
and elsewhere is a reversion to the conviction

1895.text:
that the image is always primarily severed
– shadow, phantom, nothing in itself, something

1903.text:
which invites inappropriate reverence which
commands an attention or suggests attention

1912.text:
that is in fact due only to the Holy in itself,
to God and to God’s word. And on the other

1922.text:
side of the Reformation divide, what do we
see not so much theorised  theologies and

1929.text:
philosophies of art and expressed in practice,
what we see is an attempt to recapture something

1938.text:
of the by then largely lost sense of the image’s
presence. Western Christianity had long since

1946.text:
turned its back on the Eastern theology of
the icon.

1950.text:
Indeed it was the theologians at the Emperor
Charlemagne’s Court in the 9th Century who

1954.text:
were most critical of the theories coming
out of Byzantium.   Some of their works

1961.text:
could have been, and indeed some of them were
quoted by anti-image enthusiast in the Reformation

1969.text:
debates. But what then happened on the other
side of that Reformation split was a movement

1978.text:
to re-imagine religious art as something essentially
excessive and extravagant. As art moves into

1990.text:
the era of the Baroque and the Rococo, moves
beyond mere mannerism in the 16th Century,

1998.text:
it moves towards an art which does not seek
in any sense to be representational. Look

2005.text:
up at a painted ceiling of the 17th or 18th
Century in Rome or indeed in Austria and the

2011.text:
one thing you are not likely to think is that
it represents what things look like. The excessiveness,

2019.text:
the playfulness and extravagance of Baroque
and Rococo art is one way of saying we are

2026.text:
not trying to show you what things look like,
we are trying in this experience of excess

2034.text:
to give you a sense of what cannot be said
or represented. This is a representation of

2042.text:
what goes beyond imaging. This is deliberately
ridiculous. It is sometimes liberating to

2050.text:
know that you can call some kinds of Rococo
art ridiculous in a perfectly positive sense.

2057.text:
They are meant to be. It’s a curious attempt
to re-enthrone the sacred, to justify the

2065.text:
sacred image by presenting it as something
which could have no conceivable claim to accuracy

2072.text:
and yet which in its tone of excess makes
a demand, an appropriate demand, to take you

2080.text:
beyond. 
But perhaps the most important thing about

2087.text:
the debates along this spectrum in Christian
history, the most important thing and one

2092.text:
that is often neglected in discussion is precisely
the point that theologians of icon painting

2100.text:
in the 8th and 9th Centuries insisted upon
and which the Christian East has gone on taking

2107.text:
with deep seriousness. We understand the
difference between idol, image and icon, not

2116.text:
by features that are intrinsic to them so
that you know immediately what is an idol

2122.text:
and what is an icon. The distinctions come
as we examine and think about the practices

2131.text:
in which images are embedded. How are these
images made and how are they used? Are these

2141.text:
images which are meant simply to express what
is going on in my mind, in my psyche, in my

2149.text:
heart? Are these images intended to open us
up to something else? And that of course affects

2160.text:
how we think about the making of images. The
icon painter undergoes a formidable experience

2170.text:
of spiritual preparation and askesis. There
are prayers that have to be said if you want

2177.text:
to paint a genuine icon and when it is painted
of course, it is not hung in the gallery,

2185.text:
it may be hung on the wall of a private home,
but it’s essential usage is in church. It

2193.text:
is a presence in a church, a member of the
gathering in church. It is often said that

2201.text:
the icon screen in an Orthodox church reminds
you that however many people there are in

2208.text:
the church, the holy figures represented on
screen are there with you and indeed they’re

2214.text:
there when you’re not. 
So how is an image made and for what is it

2223.text:
to be used? Is it essentially decorative? Is
it liturgical? If liturgical are we taking

2232.text:
seriously the fact that like all aspects of
liturgy it intends to transform the person

2239.text:
who sees it and reflects upon it and if it
is intended to transform then the production

2246.text:
of that image has to have something to do
with a transformed practice and a transformed

2252.text:
person. Now that may suggest an unduly austere
picture of what authentic religious art is

2260.text:
like, painted as it were, or sculpted, for
saints and by saints. That is prima face

2270.text:
a rather unlikely definition of religious
art, even if we are exceptionally generous

2276.text:
to the qualities of religious artists. Yet
there is something serious in that account

2285.text:
of how we distinguish between image, icon
and idol. Something to do with particular

2293.text:
qualities of individual and community in which
and for which representation works. A representation

2305.text:
that works properly, effectively, responsibly
we might say within the religious context

2313.text:
is one which walks precisely that tightrope
between presence and absence with which I

2319.text:
began. The tension implicit in the two Hebrew
words which I reflected upon at the beginning

2325.text:
of these remarks. And if a work is to embody
that tension between presence and absence,

2334.text:
it must come from the imagination of someone
who understands whether or not they go through

2341.text:
the esthetical processes of the Eastern icon
painter who understands something of the difference

2347.text: between divine presence and divine absence.

2351.text:
Something of the difference between a divine
presence that shakes, challenges and transforms,

2357.text:
and a divine presence that is intended to
give us comfortable religious feelings or

2363.text:
to reflect what we would like to hear and
see. And such an image is not one of course

2370.text:
which can simply be looked at casually. It
is something which because of its embodying

2378.text:
of attention between presence and absence,
we are bound to spend time with and perhaps

2387.text:
one of the most important definitions of an
image that claims to be, that plausibly claims

2393.text:
to be sacred, is that it is something which
demands time, something which cannot be assimilated,

2401.text:
taken in, in one glance. The icon of the
classical traditions of Greece and Russia

2413.text:
is certainly a work that takes time. You are
meant to spend time following its lines, its

2420.text:
contours, to understand that you are being
drawn in by an action not yours. But in spite

2426.text:
of the Eastern Christian suspicion of sculpture,
it’s also possibly true that a three dimensional

2435.text:
sculpture can have something of the same sacred
quality in that you are never going to be

2440.text:
able to see all of it at once. It demands
to be walked around, to be viewed from a whole

2448.text:
range of angles. In viewing and absorbing
a sculpture of that quality you recognise

2458.text:
that you are never going to find an optimal
place from which to see it or a final version

2465.text:
of what it is which you can capture. 
But however we express or embody that imperative

2472.text:
to take time, the point is the same. In claiming
attention the image claims time. Claiming

2484.text:
time it claims our readiness to set aside
the urge to contain and absorb the image. And

2498.text:
in evoking that readiness it warns us that
in this process we are not the sole agents

2507.text:
in control of what happens to us. We must
open ourselves to be seen as well as see.  If

2519.text:
you’re familiar with Rilke's famous poem
of an archaic statue you will remember the

2526.text:
climax of that extraordinary work. There is
no place that goes unseen. You must change

2535.text:
your life. And that perhaps encapsulates something
of what the icon, however we particularly

2546.text:
wish to define it, the icon of the Sacred
Image embodies and compels. And if we reasonably

2557.text:
clear about that, it’s possible for us to
develop because we have to develop, a continuing

2564.text:
and radical Christian critique of idolatry. Idolatry
is perhaps the major concern of great parts

2574.text:
of the Hebrew scriptures and great parts of
Christian scripture and tradition. We need,

2578.text:
forgive the jargon, a phenomenology of idolatry.
We need to be able to identify those representations

2589.text:
which rather than opening us to an alien and
challenging activity, simply reflect back

2595.text:
what we consciously or not want to see and
hear. We need to be aware that there are representations

2604.text:
that are intrinsically shadowing and shadowed,
insubstantial, impermanent, dangerous for

2614.text:
our spiritual and psychic health. Empty images
surround us in a culture often obsessed with

2626.text:
visual imaging of various kinds. And empty
imagining is part of what goes on in that

2634.text:
remarkable sub-culture that we call contemporary
economics. If we want to distinguish between

2641.text:
virtual reality and reality itself we shall
need a theology of idols, a theology of shadows. We

2651.text:
shall need to know that we are talking about
is absence; absence that can become poisonous.

2661.text:
So think through some of these issues around
the idol, image and the icon. To think through

2670.text:
to the point where we understand a little
more of what it is to be interrupted, arrested,

2678.text:
invited and almost compelled to attentive,
contemplative, time taking regard. It’s

2686.text:
to give ourselves some resources, some tools,
for identifying all those areas where images

2694.text:
can be manipulated for the control of others,
where images present themselves as alien,

2703.text:
inviting, enlarging, when in fact they simply
represent what is in us already. We may perhaps

2714.text:
be able in our openness to be authentic icons,
to grow up into being ourselves, image and

2726.text:
likeness. Image, shadows of the divine, insubstantial
in ourselves, always at risk because of the

2738.text:
nothingness at the heart of ourselves and
yet mysteriously parables at the same time. Persons’

2746.text:
speech and the relation and interaction may
be mysteriously transfiguramly continuous

2754.text:
with the action of God. In our contemplation
of the Holy Image, in our understanding of

2763.text:
how it is that certain images do open us up
to silence, we shall learn what we most need

2770.text:
to learn about growing up in a world where
we are surrounded by real and potential idols.

2779.text:
And for people of faith to learn and practice
that discipline is, I suggest, not the least

2786.text:
of the gifts of the challenges they have to
offer to our culture. Thank you for your

2812.text:
patience.
That wasn’t meant to bring the applause

2822.text:
to a stop, Archbishop, my appearance but is
an opportunity for me to thank you on behalf

2830.text:
the audience for taking the time. I’m sure
every day is an incredibly busy day in the

2836.text:
Archbishop’s life but today with announcements
and press and media I’m sure wanting to

2844.text:
take his time, to find the time to stay with
his commitment to take part in the lectures

2853.text:
today and to come and give the lecture here
is extraordinarily kind and consistent with

2861.text:
everything we know about you as a character,
Archbishop. I would like to ask, will Stephen

2869.text:
Pattison come up because Stephen is going
to say a word or two. So if he would like

2874.text:
to join us here this will be an opportunity
for him to say something. This is the second

2881.text:
time that I have heard the Archbishop speak
and I was just thinking how could one say

2889.text:
something after an incredibly scholarly talk
like that and I think on both occasions that

2896.text:
I have heard the Archbishop, I think the word
to use is ‘challenge’, to think very hard

2903.text:
while he’s talking and the fact that we
were so quiet and silent while he talked reflected

2909.text:
on the challenge to us to really try to keep
up with what is an extraordinary mind and

2920.text:
what he brings to his words compels you to
pay attention. There were so many things there

2926.text:
that struck me but forcing us to take time
and to think I thought was one of the things

2933.text:
that came through to me. But let me get out
of the way and hand over to Stephen.

2941.text:
Thank you Chancellor. After the show, the
Head of Department of Theology and the Chair

2946.text:
of the Cadbury Committee, it’s my great
pleasure to be able to thank a number of people. Obviously

2952.text:
Rowan Williams, it’s been very nice to have
him with us here today but David Morgan has

2961.text:
been with us for two weeks from America from
Duke University, the formalist interpreter

2965.text:
of visuality in North America and probably
in the world.   So we’ve been lucky to

2971.text:
have him with us. We’ve also been lucky
to have a number of artists from China and

2975.text:
from this country who’ve been doing workshops
with people of all ages, so over the two weeks

2981.text:
we’ve probably had about four or five hundred
people engaged in these lectures and I hope

2985.text:
Edward Cadbury would be well pleased that
the people of the Midlands and other places

2990.text:
have become very involved in what’s going
on here in Birmingham.    I’d like to

2997.text:
think the people who’ve helped to organise
this, particularly Caroline Ashton and Edmund

3001.text:
Tang from my own department who have made
it all mechanically possible. A lot of work

3006.text:
has gone into preparing these lectures. And
of course I would like to thank you all for

3012.text:
coming because without an audience there is
no lecturer so the audience and the lecturer

3017.text:
make each other and we’ve been very privileged
to have you all here with us this year.

3022.text:
Next year we have a series of lectures which
will be weekly on Theology and the nature

3029.text:
of Theology and studying Theology. We’re
hoping to have luminaries such as David Ford,

3034.text:
a former colleague of ours here, now in Cambridge,
and John Milbank, a graduate of our Philosophy

3039.text:
Department who has not always seen eye to
eye with David Ford and they will be both

3044.text:
talking about their visions of Theology. So
lots of interesting things to come with Cadbury

3050.text:
Lectures in the future and we hope you will
all come back next year. In the meanwhile

3056.text:
this evening we are very lucky to have the
privilege of the gallery above us being open

3063.text:
so do take some time after the lecture to
wander around the gallery and see the fine

3067.text:
collection of pictures and sculptures up there
to ponder and be challenged, I hope. And also

3074.text:
please stay and have a drink, there is a reception
which you are all warmly invited to. That

3080.text:
almost concludes my remarks, except on this
day of all days, I think this audience I suspect

3087.text:
might be sorry if we didn’t actually have
a chance to say how very much we’ve appreciated

3091.text:
everything that Rowan Williams has done for
the Church of England, for this country, for

3096.text:
our nation and for academia and from my point
of view, it’s wonderful news that he’s

3101.text:
coming back to academia because the best is
yet to come I hope! Had I known he was looking

3106.text:
for a job I might have been able to do something
about that! But there we are, Birmingham’s

3112.text:
loss is Cambridge’s gain and I hope we will
see a great deal more here, but I think we

3116.text:
would like to wish you well in your future
and thank you so much for coming today to

3122.text:
share your thoughts about icons and images
with us. We’re very grateful.
